textfields.tf: Driving level means the actual level during driving.
The height of the driving level is specified by the vehicle manufacturer, as the reference level for optimal driving characteristics.
The driving level I is achieved during calibration and is stored in the ECU as a count value.
The driving levels II and II are specified by parameterization, as difference values to driving level I.
A lower driving level II may be addressed at higher speeds to save fuel.
Mark the right statements about the driving levels I, II and III used with ECAS.
That´s wrong. Driving levels are desired or reference levels during driving. The actual level may deviate more or less from it, e.g. caused by a bumpy road.
This statement is true, that´s the characteristic of driving level I.
That´s true. The driving level specified by the manufacturer has to be stored in the ECU when calibrating the height sensors.
This statement is true. The driving levels II and III are always specified in relationship to driving level I.
That´s correct. In many cases the driving level II is addressed automatically when exceeding a certain speed threshold.
Exactly, you checked the right statements.
